climbs.name: Warm Up Arete
climbs.fa: Jeff Baldwin, Mike Beck, and Mark Russo

content.description: Possibly the hardest(?) line on this South Face. Follow the arete up from the start, cut left at the top if you need to.

Start on a large flat ledge 4 feet off the ground. Make a couple small moves, hike a high left heel, and push for the lip. Alternatively, you can dyno from midway to the lip, but be wary of the big boulder behind you if you are coming away from the wall at all.

Guidebook app calls this Wacko V3, but I think by LCC standards that'd be fairly soft
content.protection: 2 pads. One for the ground, one for the large boulder behind you. (A spotter can replace that second pad)
content.location: Eastern boulder in Warmups of White Pine. On the face pointing SW. If you’re coming down the alleyway between the two boulders from the easy face, the starting ledge is right where the low back boulder ends. First route to the right of Over the Top.

climbs.name: Vee
climbs.fa: Jeff Baldwin, Mike Beck, and Mark Russo

content.description: Starts on the south face, under the obvious "V" at the top. According to A Bouldering Guide to Utah, "climb up the face and mantle in the V-slot".
content.location: South face of the boulder, route 6 on pg. 317 of A Bouldering Guide to Utah.

content.description: Start on big slopey ledge and move up just left of arete

climbs.name: Pinch Me
climbs.fa: Jeff Baldwin, Mike Beck, and Mark Russo?

content.description: Look for a good pinch halfway or so. Follow the rail right to the lowest part of the roof to mantle up. As with most of this boulder, make it as easy or hard on yourself as you want.
content.location: Left-most climb on the South Face

content.description:
There is more than one way to skin a cat! Start on the left arete, either midway up or with a sit start variation. Traverse from the left arete to the right arete, staying low before eventually topping out on the right arete.

For a more difficult variation, traverse through the route higher up using the small crimps and textures.

Shoutout to Andrew for the harder variation and the name!
content.protection: One pad and a spotter to move it along or multiple pads if you have them.
content.location: Found on the south face of the boulder. If you have A Bouldering Guide to Utah, it's pretty much starting at route 7 and traversing to route 4 shown on pg. 317.

content.description:
From A Bouldering Guide to Utah, pg. 317: Start sitting with hands on good holds. Head up and right to underclings and edges. A long move gains a positive hold on the lip.

Variation 1: V9 - Start here and head right onto bad crimps just to the right of this problem, then to the lip.

Variation 2: V5 - Start here and head straight up.

Variation 3: V3 - Head left.
content.location: Around the corner from the main warm-up face. This problem is down the corridor on the west face of the boulder, almost to the end.

content.description:
Juggy all the way. Get creative to challenge yourself.

Found in A Bouldering Guide to Utah, "Up the big rails on the right side of the face". Rated as V0.
content.location:
Middle right of the South Face.

Route 5 on pg. 317 of A Bouldering Guide to Utah.

content.description: Leftmost route on the SW face, just next to a few scraggly bushes near the arete that points W. Sit start on juggy, very chalked right-facing sidepulls & go straight up. Called Hidden Fish V3 in the guidebook app, but that seemed a bit soft. Super safe landing — 1 pad is fine.
content.location: First warmup boulder is enormous and easy to see even from the road. Go to the face that has an alleyway with another boulder behind it

content.description: Start on small crimp just right of Closer and make long reach left.
sit start on crimps about 3.5 feet up
content.location: half way in between Closer and Ramp Move

content.description: Start down low by the down climb on a small jug. work your way up the juggy crimps on the top until you get to the jug, after that traverse into Eastern ways and top out.
content.location: next to the down climb on Over The Top Boulder

climbs.name: Eastern Ways
climbs.fa: Jeff Baldwin, Mike Beck, and Mark Russo?

content.description:
Great line on the Eastern face. Start low edges. High step to gain the side-pull. Move up the tallest part of the boulder.

Can be found on pg. 317 of A Bouldering Guide to Utah.
content.location: Just right of the SE arete.

content.description: Sit start on holds about 3 feet up and go straight up via crimps
content.location: A few feet right of Wacko
